comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Cool, athough I wonder why they use cylindrical hoppers to transport bulk cement (it would be in powder form). We usually use more squarish ones here in North America, just seems easier to make. I wonder if they discharge from the bottom or the top of the car?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
22919290@N08
comment._content:
A good record shot at Kildare. 
Yes indeed these were CIE's four wheel bulk cement wagons, built largely in two batches between 1964 and 1972. They originally carried an ivory livery, as depicted in O'Dea's photo. 
They were nicknamed 'bubbles' due to their shape, a design which helped prevent the liquid cement from drying during transit. They shouldn't exactly be described as hoppers, as hoppers are usually open wagons. The cement was loaded/discharged from an open top hatch, and by a pipe nearer to the wagon frame.
During the early years of the 'bubbles', a guard's brakevan would be marshalled at the front and rear of the train, as seen in the photo, even though the wagons were vacuum braked. This practice was phased out however by 1970. The train is possibly en-route from the cement works at Athy to the Cabra bulk terminal in Dublin City. Incidentally, the last 'bubbles' were finally withdrawn in 2009, some 45 years in service.

comment.author: 75365254@N02
comment._content:
These look like the trains which used to go to Cement factory at Carnlough Road, Cabra West, Dublin 7. The tracks ran under Cabra Road. Did these trains come from Kildare and use the old line through the park? Also any information or photos of the junction off the main Connolly line running along the back of the factories? (Think it was called Liffey Junction?)
There is also an old dis-used track at 21 Cabra Road just before St. Peter's Church, Phibsborough, Dublin 7. Any information on this line?

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/75365254@N02] 

That's right about Cabra, these wagons indeed went there as it was the main terminal for bulk cement in Dublin. They would travel via the tunnel under Phoenix Park having diverged from the Cork line at Islandbridge Jct.

O'Dea would have photos of Liffey Jct which is in north Cabra on the Sligo line. That is where the former main line diverged towards the old Broadstone terminus, the trackbed is still in situ and it is the one near St Peter's Church. It closed to main line trains in 1937, run down by the 1960s and finally lifted in 1970/2.

comment.author: 25652667@N06
comment._content: Great photo. Cabra was a storage depot (road tankers would be filled here for local delivery to concrete plants etc) that was served by the factory at Platin. Athy was served by the factory at Limerick until March 2005. Athy is the Tegral roof tile factory, it used a special type of cement. Other bulk depots around the country were; Cork, Athenry, Sligo, Tullamore & Belfast. Sadly no more.

comment.author: 88431102@N04
comment._content:
Judging by the year it was taken January 1967, its probably a laden bulk cement traveling from Limerick cement factory to Cabra cement depot, and its laden as you can see from the axle springs are in the flat position.
These wagons never carried ''liquid cement'' or ''ready mix'' but bulk powder compressed in by air, handy for construction sites, saving having to open hundreds of bags on a site.
If it was ''ready mix'' the cement would be hard in a matter of hours, they where bubble in shape to stop the powder from sticking to the sides on the inside.
